ABSTRACT

WOLLINGER, Wagner. D esenvolvimento de m√©todos de espectroscopia de RMN e MRC aplicad os √† metrologia qu√≠mica . Rio de Janeiro, 2 018. Tese (Doutorado em Ci√™ncias) ‚Äì Instituto de Qu√≠mica, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, 2018.

NMR is a primary method of measurement that provides quantitative traceable results without the need for a standard of the same measurand. Despite the advantages of the 1H nucleus, such as high sensitivity, short relaxation times and widespread distribution in organic compounds, some molecules present only labile H atoms, or the 1H peaks of a sample may overlap with impurities. With the CHORAD scheme ‚Äì a combination of the pulse sequence CHORUS and adiabatic modulation for proton decoupling ‚Äì this study has shown that 13C NMR can be used for quantitative analyses with a bias smaller than 2 % and expanded uncertainty of 0.7 % (k=2). Since 13C is found with significant non -statistic isotope fractionation, all the peaks of the sample and internal standard should be integrated and their bulk 13C abundances obtained by isotope ratio mass spectrometry (IRMS) must be considered to meet quantitative requirements. This approach also proved to be suitable for studies of site-specific 13C distribution and led to better heteronuclear decoupling when compared with the use of adiabatic decoupling with ordinary hard 90¬∞ pulses, a combination extensively reported in the li terature over the last decade. An examination of the molecules studied in this work and others from the literature revealed an overall trend in the 13C intramolecular profile ‚Äì quaternary positions are often 13C-enriched. A potential contribution of 1JCH coupling to these results is discussed. In the following phase of this work, a set of potential internal standards for qNMR was proposed ‚Äì maleic acid, dimethyl sulfone, hydrogen potassium phthalate and dimethyl terephthalate. This was first selected for th e production of a 200 -unit batch of certified reference material (CRM). The analytical performance of 13C NMR was not considered sufficient for very accurate and precise purity studies. Batch characterization was therefore carried out by 1H qNMR compared w ith other methods such as freezing point depression and mass balance, a procedure based on the determination of impurities. Uncertainty of 1H qNMR was three -fold smaller than that for 13C nucleus, which had been highly influenced by the IRMS uncertainty of isotope abundance measurements. Even though, mass balance was chosen for CRM value assignment because it presented the smallest vii

uncertainty and to follow BIPM recommendation to use methods other than qNMR to characterize internal standards intended for qN MR. This work presents the implications of the use of chromatographic area results, without external calibration, to assess homogeneity and stability in isochronous designs. By contrast, mass balance presented better repeatability and so was selected for t he evaluation of homogeneity and stability. The CRM developed for dimethyl terephthalate presented neither significant heterogeneity nor any instability trend. The certified value was (999.88 ¬± 0.58) mg/g ( k=2). Depending on the outcome of an internal audi t scheduled for the following months , this value may be slightly modified. This CRM will be considered valid for 2 years and its stability should be annually monitored by 1H NMR or mass balance.
Keywords: Chemical Metrology. Certified Reference Materials. 13C NMR. 1H NMR. Measurement Uncertainty.
